before_start: {"blocks":[{"key":"59jcm","text":"The protocol should be carried out in a clean environment, ideally on a dedicated PCR workstation or on a separate bench used only for this purpose. Before starting, clean the bench and wipe any piece of equipment with RNAseZAP or 0.5% sodium hypochlorite. Rinse with nuclease-free water to avoid corrosion of delicate equipment.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"anqqb","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"7oh0o","text":"Work quickly and preferably on ice.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"3qklj","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"8ncdp","text":"Reagent mixes should be prepared shortly before use.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"6eh0r","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"80i7q","text":"Mix thoroughly each mix before dispensing. For higher accuracy use liquid handling robots and/or nanodispensers whenever possible. In FLASH-Seq we use the I.DOT (​​Dispendix) for all the dispensing steps and the Fluent 780 liquid handling robot (Tecan) for sample cleanup, reagent transfers and pooling.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"be84u","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"4v3jm","text":"The protocol described below is meant to be carried out in 384-well plates. When using 96-well plates, we recommend using 5 times larger volume to guarantee successful cell sorting and prevent evaporation issues.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"8o20q","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"7emhn","text":"Always use LoBind plates and tubes (especially for long-term storage) to prevent the cDNA/DNA from sticking to plastic.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{}}

description: {"blocks":[{"key":"ek09d","text":"Building upon the existing Smart-seq2/3 workflows, we developed FLASH-seq (FS), a new full-length scRNA-seq method capable of detecting a significantly higher number of genes than both previous versions, requiring limited hands-on time and with a great potential for customization.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"3copk","text":"FLASH-seq Low-Amplification (FS-LA), represents FS quickest iteration, generating sequencing-ready libraries in 4.5 hours by removing intermediate cleanups and QC steps and without sacrificing performance. FS-LA is the best choice when a large number of plates need to be processed in parallel.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{}}

groups.title: Human Cell Atlas Method Development Community

guidelines: {"blocks":[{"key":"5p03a","text":"FLASH-Seq Low-Amplification (FS-LA) is a variation of FLASH-Seq, where the cDNA after RT is amplified for a limited number of cycles, in order to reduce PCR bias and reduce library preparation time. Three parameters need to be considered when setting up a FS-LA experiment:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"93s9s","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"dnrie","text":"1 --- RNA content of the cell type: this is going to determine how many pre-amplification cycles are required to generate enough cDNA for the tagmentation, while minimizing unmapped / intergenic reads. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"evhqd","text":"⇒ The exact number of PCR cycles cannot be determined based on the wet-lab results but rather evaluated based on the sequencing results. We recommend performing a pilot study on a subset of cells processed with varying numbers of PCR cycles and choose the value that minimises the background noise.  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"deaor","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"2khna","text":"2 --- Reaction volume: as the cDNA is not purified prior to tagmentation, it is important to dilute enough the salts and additives of the RT-PCR mix. We recommend diluting the unpurified cDNA 10 times for the best results, although lower dilutions might also work. The increased costs associated with higher reaction volumes are generally negligible when working with in-house Tn5 transposase. When working with the ATM mix contained in the NexteraXT kit we recommend pre-diluting your cDNA 1:10 and performing the tagmentation reaction in 2 µL.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"6vl22","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"7arni","text":"3 --- Amount of Tn5: that needs to be adjusted case by case, depending on the cell type, number of pre-amplification cycles as well as specific activity of each Tn5 batch. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"esjo4","text":"⇒ The exact value can be evaluated at the wet-lab stage based on the library size distribution.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"f2v2i","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"39vls","text":"As a guideline, we recommend choosing 10-12 PCR cycles when working with large cells and/or cell lines (i.e. HEK 293 cells) and 14-16 cycles when working with cells containing smaller amounts of mRNA (i.e. PBMC). Refer to FLASH-Seq manuscript and extended files #2 for more information (Hahaut et al). ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{}}

Look for abnormalities such as read piles falling in intergenic or centromeric regions.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"atp7n","text":"No single-cell RNA sequencing protocol is perfect and non-specific priming, genomic DNA contaminations, … can happen but should represent rare events.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"6mej4","text":"Recurrent soft-clipping could also indicate the presence of sequencing adaptor left-overs that could affect the mapping rate. {"blocks":[{"key":"2e5d3","text":"Count matrix","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":12}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"d0udh","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"8gsni","text":"Finally, t​he number of reads associated with each gene can be obtained as follows:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"d7k3m","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":[]},{"key":"d99mn","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"command","mutability":"","data":{"id":9787,"name":"featureCounts -T 1 -t exon -g gene_name --fracOverlap 0.25 -a \"$GTF\" -o \"$ID\"_ReadCount.featureCounts.gencode.txt \"$ID\"_Aligned.sortedByCoord.filtered.bam","os_name":null,"os_version":null,"command_name":"","description":null,"can_edit":0,"guid":"FEAB7D305B2211ECBF77C3237A90C99D"}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"erjms","text":"Post-processing","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":15}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"2ek1j","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"3tpsc","text":"The post-processing steps will vary depending on the question at hand. The online book “Orchestrating Single-Cell Analysis with Bioconductor” (https://bioconductor.org/books/release/OSCA/) is a gold mine of information that can be used to help you design your own pipeline. Alternatively, Seurat (R, https://satijalab.org/seurat/) or scanpy (python, https://scanpy.readthedocs.io/en/stable/) provide tools compatible with FLASH-seq data. Given their similarities, we currently recommend using Smart-seq2 guidelines when processing FLASH-seq data.
